title: NRA Donor Files Suit Over CEO's Expenses
summary: Complaint comes as gun-rights organization is facing internal turmoil and an investigation by New York's attorney general. A donor to the National Rifle Association filed a lawsuit against the gun-rights group, seeking class-action status, and claiming the group's funding solicitations were "intentionally and materially false" because the NRA spent donated funds on executive perks, large legal fees, and other expenses unrelated to the group's core mission.

title: Stephen Ross's Planned Trump Fundraiser Draws Calls for Boycotts
summary: Developer's Hamptons donor event elicits backlash from celebrities, users of fitness clubs owned by Mr. Ross. title: Fox Corp. Will Pursue More Content, Chief Says
summary: Network reports higher revenue, fueled by cable and broadcast television. Fox Corp. , which made two deals so far this week, will continue to look for acquisitions to boost its content holdings and forge closer ties to its audience, Chief Executive Lachlan Murdoch said.

title: Nearly 700 Held After Immigration Raids in Mississippi
summary: Action surpasses previous largest worksite enforcement operation, which led to more than 280 arrests of suspected undocumented immigrants. U.S. immigration officials raided several food-processing plants in Mississippi on Wednesday, detaining 680 people suspected of being in the country illegally in what Immigration and Customs Enforcement called the largest single state worksite enforcement action.

title: FedEx to End Ground Deliveries for Amazon
summary: Parcel giant severs ties with e-commerce giant, which is building its own delivery services. FedEx Corp. said it was ending its contract to deliver Amazon.com Inc. packages through its ground network, essentially severing ties with one of the world's biggest shippers and gambling it is better off filling its trucks with other customers' goods.

title: Bond Yields Fall, Sparking Volatility in Stocks
summary: S&P 500 and Dow industrials end the day near flat after heightened volatility. A flight to safety that drove down bond yields globally sparked renewed volatility in the stock market Wednesday, highlighting uncertainty about how the trade and currency battle between the U.S. and China will play out.

title: Booking Holdings Reports Higher-Than-Expected Results
summary: Revenue at online-travel company up 8.8%, with gross travel bookings up 5%. Booking Holdings Inc. reported higher-than-expected profit and revenue in the latest quarter, boosted by what its chief executive called a solid start to the summer travel season.

title: Puerto Rico Swears In New Governor After High Court Ousts Predecessor
summary: Wanda Vázquez becomes third leader in less than a week after high court rules Pedro Pierluisi relied on unconstitutional law to take power. Puerto Rico Justice Secretary Wanda Vázquez was sworn in as governor after the U.S. territory's Supreme Court ruled unanimously that Pedro Pierluisi's swearing-in last week was unconstitutional, extending the political turmoil that has paralyzed government there.

title: Yemen Separatists Storm Presidential Palace in Aden
summary: Clash deepens rift between factions in Saudi-led coalition fighting Houthi rebels. A similar online forum, Gab.com, was allegedly used by the shooter who killed 11 people at a Pittsburgh synagogue in October. The Dayton shooter, Connor Betts, spent much of his time raving on Twitter .

title: Vive la Finance! A Chic Economics Museum Opens in Paris
summary: Housed in an old mansion-turned-bank, the interactive Citeco economics museum aims to appeal to everyone from 8-year-old penny pinchers to seasoned hedgefunders. LEAVE IT TO the French to conceive a chic museum dedicated to finance. In June, Cité de l'Économie (or Citéco) opened inside an 1882 edifice in the 17th arrondissement. With vaulted gothic doorways and intricate wooden wainscoting, the building itself is as genteel and old-school as you'd expect from a Parisian mansion turned bank turned museum. But the very-2019 exhibits impudently grab your attention with animated videos, digital projections and interactive games. In the "Players" section, for example, visitors are asked to place everyday objects (jeans, a computer) in an airport-style scanner to learn about production and globalization.

title: What Can We Do About Mass Shootings?
summary: It is the responsibility of Congress to legislate logical solutions to help prevent another tragedy. It must do so without violating our Second Amendment.. The motivations of the shooters in the two most recent mass shootings, and all the others in recent years, are varied ("Two Mass Shootings Leave 29 Dead," Page One, Aug. 5). Some were sparked by domestic violence incidents, some by racial animus, some by white nationalists' hatred of Jews and blacks, and others by the chaos of mental derangement. What do they all have in common? All are shootings by men typically using semiautomatic weapons with large-capacity, detachable magazines. The old National Rifle Association trope that people kill, guns do not, absolutely misses the point. There is no doubt that our country's lax gun purchase and registration laws contribute to the carnage. Rage plus ready access to a weapon of mass destruction is a toxic brew that breeds tragic outcomes.

title: Jerome Powell's Useless Precaution
summary: Mr. Powell also has shot the last bullet in the Fed's monetary gun that will be needed when an overdue recession does come.. Federal Reserve Chairman Jerome Powell has shredded the Fed's credibility ("Stocks Drop After Fed Cuts Rates," Page One, Aug. 1). With interest rates already historically low and the economy humming (other than the disruption from President Trump's erratic trade policies), Mr. Powell also has shot the last bullet in the Fed's monetary gun that will be needed when an overdue recession does come.

title: Writer Jia Tolentino on Her Obsession With 'Disgusting' Jean Shorts
summary: The author and New Yorker staff writer, whose new book of essays 'Trick Mirror' is out this week, describes her lifelong affinity for beat-up denim cutoffs. GROWING UP IN Texas, I attended an evangelical private school whose thorough strictness was expressed most clearly in the dress code. Boys wore slacks; girls wore pleated skirts in khaki and slate gabardine; for weekly chapel, everyone wore white oxford shirts and loafers. Summers, after so much starchy biblical confinement, came as an all-consuming release. This was Houston, and so it was mostly humid and hot to the point of unearthliness-three-digit temperatures were normal for months. But I loved the heat, the burning dazzle during the daytime, the way the grass stayed warm long into the night. On my suburban cul-de-sac, with its tiny pirate-ship playground and built-in gang of like-minded neighbors, you could play outside every minute you weren't sleeping. And so, on the first day of summer, I'd ceremonially put on a pair of cutoff jean shorts and a T-shirt-what deep spiritual freedom!-and for months I'd hardly take this other, far more satisfying uniform off.

title: India's Central Bank Cuts Rates as Economy Struggles

summary: Former governor of Utah will return home after a tenure marked by deteriorating relations. WASHINGTON-Jon Huntsman, the U.S. ambassador to Russia, will resign the post in early October and return home ahead of what is widely seen as a bid to again seek election as Utah's governor.

title: China Warns Hong Kong It Will Intervene if Situation Deteriorates
summary: A senior Chinese official in charge of Hong Kong affairs issued a dire assessment of the situation in the territory after more than two months of protests. BEIJING-A senior Chinese official in charge of Hong Kong affairs warned that Beijing would intervene if the local government proved unable to contain the violent protests, the most explicit threat of intervention to date from the central government.

title: Warren Calls for $85 Billion Investment in Public Broadband
summary: Democratic presidential candidate makes appeal to voters in rural areas, where access to high-speed internet remains sparse. WASHINGTON-Democratic presidential candidate Elizabeth Warren is calling for an $85 billion investment in publicly owned and operated broadband networks to expand internet access across the country.

title: Simone Biles Is Still the World's Best Gymnast
summary: With the 2020 Olympics approaching, most of the sport's familiar faces are missing. Here are the new athletes to watch.. U.S. women gymnasts are still world-dominant despite the sex-abuse scandal that has swept away most of their sport's national infrastructure. But beyond Simone Biles, now widely regarded as her sport's greatest athlete ever, the women who will fill out the U.S. roster at the Tokyo next summer are relatively little known.

title: Behind Yuan Move, China Concedes Its Economy Needs a Boost
summary: The case for a weaker currency is clearer as the country's growth has downshifted. SHANGHAI-China's abrupt devaluation of the yuan this week is an acknowledgment from Beijing that its domestic economy needs help, a vulnerability that Chinese policy makers have played down during the escalating trade conflict with the U.S.

title: Short-Seller Accuses Litigation-Finance Firm of 'Meaningless Metrics'
summary: Muddy Waters claims the company aggressively marked up the value of legal cases. LONDON-U.S. short-seller Muddy Waters accused the litigation-finance firm Burford Capital Ltd. of poor governance and mismarking the value of legal cases it invests in, wiping around 50% off the value of the U.K. firm's shares.

title: Wood Pellets Draw Fire as Alternative to Coal
summary: A lawsuit says European policy on using pellets will increase greenhouse-gas emissions; 'burning gas would release far less carbon dioxide,' expert says. The wood-pellet business is thriving based on the argument that trees are a clean-energy alternative to coal, but the science behind it is facing challenges from researchers who say cutting and burning trees takes a heavy environmental toll.

title: Afghan Blast Claimed by Taliban Kills at Least 14
summary: Car bomb is detonated days after U.S. and insurgency say talks to end 18-year war are making progress. KABUL-Taliban insurgents detonated a car bomb near the entrance to a police station in the Afghan capital on Wednesday, killing at least 14 people and wounding scores more, as peace talks aimed at ending the nearly 18-year war continued.

title: The Weak Spots in China's Dollar Empire
summary: The value of offshore dollar bonds issued by Chinese corporations has more than tripled since 2014, with real-estate borrowing particularly high. How should investors feel about the effect of the falling yuan on China's dollar debtors? It depends where you look, and whom you believe.

title: Sharing Tech Won't Vindicate UTC-Raytheon Megamerger
summary: An analysis of both companies' patent portfolios confirms that they have little in common. Aerospace giant United Technologies and defense company Raytheon tout the advantages of combining their technological expertise through the megamerger they announced in June. A look at their patent portfolios suggests that any such gains will in fact be scant.

title: Riches to Rags: Hedge Funds and Retailers Don't Mix
summary: Hedge-fund managers have lorded over the decline of retailers from Sears to Barneys. Barneys New York owner Richard Perry isn't the only deep-pocketed money manager to watch over the decline of a storied retailer.

title: Cable Provider Altice Looks to Help Customers Ditch the Remote
summary: Smart speaker with technology from Amazon.com's Alexa to be introduced later this year. Cable operator Altice USA Inc. is hoping to nestle itself in consumers' living rooms with the launch of a new at-home speaker, Altice Amplify, that includes technology from Amazon.com Inc.'s Alexa.

title: Glencore to Close Massive Mine as Economic Woes Hit Metals
summary: Closure will remove around 20% of the global market's cobalt supply. Glencore PLC's first-half earnings fell by a third and the commodities giant said it is closing one of its largest copper and cobalt mines, as concerns over the global economy and the trade war between the U.S. and China hit commodity prices.

title: Auto-Parts Giant Slams Brakes on Engines Amid Shift to Electric
summary: Germany's Continental to cut investment in conventional engine parts as major auto makers sharpen focus on electric vehicles. BERLIN-One of the world's biggest car-parts makers is preparing for a future without the internal combustion engine-the machine that has been at the heart of the auto industry for well over a century.

title: Entercom Communications to Acquire Two Podcast Companies
summary: Deals will give company a presence in several facets of podcasting, from production to distribution and monetization. Entercom Communications Corp. has reached deals for a pair of podcast companies, moving the second-largest U.S. radio broadcaster by revenue more heavily into the nascent business.

title: Arizona Iced Tea Maker Turns to Weed
summary: Beverage maker reaches licensing deal with U.S. cannabis company for new line of gummies, vape pens and drinks. The company behind Arizona Iced Tea is getting into the market for marijuana-infused gummies and drinks in the U.S. and Canada, seeking new avenues for growth after losing ground in its core tea business.

title: Facebook's Rebranding Could Faceplant
summary: Facebook's move to add its name to Instagram and WhatsApp platforms could fuel or cut the growth engine. Transparency is noble in theory, less so in practice.

title: Lyft and Uber to Post Earnings Amid Legislation Concerns
summary: Lyft reports after the closing bell, Uber reports after the bell on Thursday. Lyft Inc. and Uber Technologies Inc. are set to report their quarterly earnings this week, their second as public companies since IPOs in March and May, respectively. The reception thus far hasn't been great: both ride-hailing competitors are trading well below their IPO prices. Here's what to watch as Lyft reports after the market closes on Wednesday and Uber files after the close of trading on Thursday.

title: Medical Schools Are Pushed to Train Doctors for Climate Change
summary: Movement backed by American Medical Association starts to grow, though content can be hard to fit into an already-packed curriculum. More doctors, health organizations and students are pushing for medical education to include climate change, saying that physicians and other health-care workers need to prepare for the risks associated with rising global temperatures.

title: New Tax Laws Drive More Americans Into Muni Bonds
summary: High earners hit hardest by overhaul seek to generate tax-free income. Investors in high-tax states like New York and California are piling into municipal bonds this year, fueled in part by the 2017 tax overhaul that raised tax burdens for some high-income households.

title: Russian Media Muffle Protest Images, Broadcast Beef Kebabs
summary: President Putin is trying to stop demonstrations without stoking further discontent over a poor economy, a pension revamp and endemic corruption. MOSCOW-As Russian riot police violently suppressed pro-democracy demonstrations across Moscow, detaining around 1,000 people, some pro-Kremlin state news channels featured a different top news item: a city-sponsored barbecue festival on the leafy banks of the Moscow River.

title: A New Risk Factor in Corporate Disclosures: Active Shooters
summary: Several companies have added language to securities filings warning investors about the possible financial impact of gun violence. A handful of public companies have begun quietly warning investors about how gun violence could affect their financial performance.

title: Finally, Tracking for the Hotel Shuttle Van
summary: Hotel chains are upgrading apps to check in customers, pre-order food, track shuttle vans and other services. Dulles, Va.

title: IBM Says Security Concerns Should Benefit Its Hybrid Cloud Business
summary: Incidents like the Capital One breach boost the case for the company's hybrid cloud, which takes a 'full stack' security approach, executives say. International Business Machines Corp. is betting that its strategy of giving big companies the flexibility to run their data and applications anywhere they want will help it win over enterprises concerned about cybersecurity.

title: New Nintendo Switch to Have IGZO Display From Sharp
summary: Videogame maker plans to refresh its lineup with new models this month and next. TOKYO- Sharp Corp. will supply its IGZO display panels to Nintendo Co. 's new videogame machines, a top executive said, a boost for Sharp as it tries to spread its version of advanced display technology.

title: China Keeps Official Yuan Rate Just Stronger Than 7 Per Dollar
summary: Central bank avoids moving official rate beyond symbolic level. China set a daily anchor for trading in its currency at the weakest since 2008 but again avoided moving that official rate beyond the symbolic 7-yuan-per-dollar level.

title: Tax Dodging Made June a Record Month for Luxury Real Estate
summary: More than $4.8 billion in property changed hands, marking the highest monthly amount since at least 2003. June was the biggest month ever for sales of luxury residential real estate in New York City, as a looming July 1 tax increase sent hundreds of buyers scrambling to close deals.

title: U.S. Stocks Regain Ground, Yuan Stabilizes
summary: Major indexes rebound as investors see potential buying opportunity, bet on further rate cuts. U.S. stocks recouped some of their losses Tuesday after China backed off from a further escalation in the country's trade and currency dispute with Washington.

title: Pepper...and Salt
summary: Resume Subscription. We are delighted that you'd like to resume your subscription.

title: Brokers Bank on Your Cash, but Some Are Breaking From the Pack
summary: Fidelity is automatically sweeping new clients' cash into a money fund with a higher yield than what is paid by many other brokerages. Fidelity Investments said it has sweetened the deal for customers holding cash there, the latest salvo in the price war playing out among brokerages competing for clients' assets.

title: NRA Chief Sought Help of Group's Ad Agency in Trying to Buy $5 Million Mansion
summary: Wayne LaPierre's dealings with firm being probed by New York attorney general. National Rifle Association Chief Executive Wayne LaPierre was in discussions to have the group's then-outside advertising agency help him buy a Dallas mansion last year for more than $5 million, but the deal fell through, according to people familiar with the matter.

title: Tiffany Cabán Concedes in Queens District Attorney Primary
summary: Borough President Melinda Katz wins by slim margin after contested results. Tiffany Cabán, a progressive insurgent candidate who ran for Queens district attorney on a campaign of criminal-justice reform, conceded Tuesday night, more than a month after a contested Democratic primary election.

title: Tired of Waiting for Brexit, Britons Munch Through Nutella Stockpiles
summary: Worriers squirreled away mozzarella and tea in case a messy exit from the EU sparked shortages; some are breaking into their stashes. LONDON-Britain's Brexit preppers have been stockpiling for months. Now their revolution is eating itself.

title: Judge Blocks Arkansas Laws Banning Abortion
summary: Laws are the latest in a wave across states found to run afoul of U.S. Supreme Court precedent. A federal judge has blocked a series of abortion restrictions in Arkansas, preventing laws from taking effect that would have closed the state's last surgical abortion clinic and prohibited the procedure after 18 weeks of pregnancy.

title: Flavor Company Reports Potential Bribery by Company It Acquired
summary: International Flavors & Fragrances said it disclosed to U.S. and Israeli authorities potentially improper payments by executives at Frutarom. A New York-based flavor company disclosed potential bribes in Russia and Ukraine by an Israeli company it acquired last year.

title: FBI Probes Shooters' Motives Amid Wider Alarm Over Attacks
summary: Federal officials look at the role ideology played in shootings in California, Texas and Ohio. The FBI opened an investigation into what role ideology played in the weekend's mass shooting in Ohio and one a week earlier in California, part of a widening federal inquiry into the recent violence as domestic terrorism.
